ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I didn't love all of the discussions that we had--I'm not sure how to improve those, but I just didn't think we were engaged enough or interested by all of the questions posed in class. Most of the invited guests were interesting. Overall, I'm grateful for the exposure to the land trust community that I received in this class that I wouldn't have received elsewhere.

I didn't know much about land conservation before taking this course. I got the broad survey I wanted, plus met numerous leaders in the field.I can't say enough about Brad's intelligence and skill in a course like this. From engaging students in dialogue, introducing and synthesizing a range of topics, and bringing in really interesting speakers, Brad just excels at this course.

Land conservation is my focus here so this course was extremely valuable. The guest speakers were very informative and interesting. I wish we had the title tracking workshop but there are other opportunities to get that.
This was a great course from a theoretical and practitioner point of view.

The class is based around a clinical project in which students partner with various local land conservation organizations. The clinical project was a wonderful opportunity to begin to think about how the various topics and discussions we had in the class portion could play out in a professional setting. The clinical project is a wonderful component of this course.
Some of the additional workshops--Peter Forbes, the all-day course with the TNC guy--were fantastic.
The class is very well planned...from the weekly readings and response papers to the format of the class (discussion then guest lecture/discussion). Runs very smoothly.
wide overview of land conservation in the US
See above.

The guest speakers were outstanding and gave a great feel for the width and breadth of people working on land conservation issues.Our clinical project was interesting, fulfilling, and a real pleasure. Working with real people on land conservation issues is a great experience.

The speakers were great, the class approached conservation from a number of different perspectives, and I really appreciated the underlying questions of "who are we conserving land for?" and "what drives people to want to conserve land?"
Professor, class format/discussion, clinical

The course has a well-defined structure and direction, and the material builds over the course of the semester. Yet, each week we had a different practitioner in as a guest speaker to share their experiences on a specific topic. The course thus drew upon a diversity of experiences and perspectives but also succeeded in maintaining a coherent direction and additive material.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: the speakers sometimes took things off in their own direction. I wanted to learn more from Brad. I would have liked to spend a lot less time going around and talking about other people's projects.

I sometimes had mixed feelings about the question and reaction writing assignments we did every week. I think they should be kept, but I wonder if there's a way to keep them fresh and not seem rote. Maybe I could have done better at that myself.

It would be nice to make the online forum more like a forum and less like an area for simply posting. Many folks said remarkable things- it would be nice to air them out a little bit via more discussion online.It would be nice to talk about energy siting issues and how energy folks can work with land conservationists.
Can't think of anything.
Out of class time sessions

Clinical projects can be hit or miss, and I was working on a clinical project that did not feel as if it was a big priority to the partner organization. I was a little down on the project until the very end, when I really started to write the plan - I really enjoyed producing the plan and finalizing the project and in retrospect got more out of the project than I had realized during the course of the semester. I think that was more a function of my ability todevote time to it rather than the project.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Available, helpful, in class and outside. Very committed to their role as TA& professor.
Very knowledgeable and available!
great
Excellent.

Brad was always willing to stay after class and clear up any questions.Walker did an excellent job on the organizational front and she also did really well guiding the discussion in class. She was also very responsive to emails.
They were both as responsive as I could ask for.
Great

Both the instructor and TA were available and very willing to help. Although I did not approach them with formal questions or concerns, they made sure to stay abreast of developments in clinical projects and were sure to make it clear that if we had any questions they would be more than willing to sit down to discuss.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I was looking for an introduction to the entire field of land conservation. No past experience but plans to continue involvement in the field after this class!
interested in conservation generally
I'm an MF and this course wasn't required but was very helpful.
The clinical aspect of this course provided me a professional opportunity to work on land conservation. As such, it provided great hands on experience.
It is integral to any program in land conservation.
Must take course for anyone interested in land work

As an MEM interested in land conservation, I really enjoyed this course as an opportunity to explore all aspects of conservation - the nuts and bolts and mechanisms of pursuing conservation and more importantly the more nuanced philosophical questions about what we are doing and how we should be approaching it. This course then fit extremely well in my program of study here, and, together with other courses and experiences I had the opportunity to explore this semester, has helped shift and reshape my understanding of conservation and how I will be working in the future.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: For exposure to additional conservation strategies.
See above. Wanted to explore jobs in open space preservation and land conservation.
I hope to work in forest conservation and so this class was a great foundation course for me. It also allowed me to view conservation in a broader and more comprehensive context.
Because I want to start a career in land conservation.
Because I want to invest in land

I am pursuing a course of study here to prepare to engage in land conservation work when I leave. This course then was a natural fit to begin to explore not only the practical side of land conservation but as I mentioned above, the deeper, underlying philosophical questions as well.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes! Took a bit to catch up to the level of experience of others in the class (not sure I ever did) but I know that I will draw on and refer back to the skills and advice gained from guest speakers, other students, Brad, and Walker in the future.
for the most part
Yes.
Yes. This course is fantastic.
Yes. It surpassed them.
Yes

The course was excellent and lived up to my expectations. I had been warned prior to the course that the course will be made or broken by the clinical project. I wasn't completely psyched with my clinical project throughout the semester (although by the end I was happy with it and feel I was able to complete a useful task for an organization), but I feel the rest of the class had more than enough merit on its own to make the course worthwhile.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
same as 17
Yes
Yes. The clinical work pushed me quite a bit and it felt great to deliver on a professional project.
Yes and more.
Yes

I expected the course to be excellent and it indeed was. In another sense, I got more than I expected. This course, in combination with other courses I took this semester has reshaped the way I think about conservation and how I will be engaging in work in the future. It is always exciting to look back on a course and see that progression.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages: Ilearned a lot and was more invested in the course because of this -- and I actually was able to use a number of points learned from lectures in the class in the report we submitted to our client. I felt proud about our work. No disadvantages!
Working with someone similarly interested in the project but with different personality traits and skills to offer--often complemented each other's working styles.
good to learn from peers
I like our clinical project. Working with my dour partner was the biggest challenge, but I found ways! I got some nice experience with a land trust/trail group through the clinical.

My partner and I completed our project- it involved lots of intense one-on-one work time as well as delegation of certain responsibilities.In terms of disadvantages- they were logistical only. It is hard to coordinate schedules but it is a good exercise in time management.
Our clinical project was a very fascinating trail corridor plan for the Connecticut Forest and Parks Association. I really enjoyed seeing how this part of conservation acquisitions is conducted.
My partner was great and helpked me learn more

Group work can be challenging from a logistical standpoint and also from an engagement-standpoint. I enjoyed the opportunity to engage in the project, but did not have a partner that was equally willing to invest time in the project.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Think carefully about your clinical and go out to dinner with the guests and Brad as often as possible.

1. Pick a project you are really interested in.2. Read some of the readings well and comment directly on them- don't skim and then write vagaries.3. Meet with Brad or the TA to discuss your project.4. Go to all the voluntary workshops.

If you want a career in land conservation this course will be an asset to you. It is extremely practical and non-scientific, however. I can't see it furthering any research ambitions someone might have, but then again, that is not how its billed.
If you are interested in land, you need to take this course

The clinical project is important, and think hard about what you want to get out of the project. I simply read the project descriptions and keyed in on ones that sounded interesting. I would, in retrospect, try to think about what skills or knowledge I wanted to develop through the semester, and try to select a project based on that. I didn't take advantage of the post-class dinner opportunities during the semester and wish I had - do so if you can.
